summary.title: Online Payments Processing Platform
summary.description:
This threat model has been provided by the OWASP Threat Model Cookbook:
threat-model-cookbook/Flow Diagram/payment

text.text:
Demo threat model for an online Payments Processing Platform
provided by the OWASP Threat Model Cookbook:
threat-model-cookbook/Flow Diagram/payment

data.name:
Demo threat model for an online Payments Processing Platform
provided by the OWASP Threat Model Cookbook:
threat-model-cookbook/Flow Diagram/payment

threats.title: Customer Identity Spoofing
threats.description: The Customer actor is located in the Customer/Internet trust boundary and initiates authentication flows. Without proper identity verification, an attacker could spoof legitimate customer identities to gain unauthorized access to the merchant system.
threats.mitigation: Implement strong multi-factor authentication and identity verification mechanisms for customer login processes.

threats.title: Client-Side Tampering of Payment Data
threats.description: Customer Client process handles payment flows and is located in the Customer/Internet boundary. Client-side code could be tampered with to modify payment amounts or redirect payments.
threats.mitigation: Implement server-side validation of all payment amounts and use secure client-side libraries with integrity checks.

threats.title: Information Disclosure from Client
threats.description: Customer Client process handles sensitive payment information and communicates across trust boundaries. Sensitive data could be exposed through client-side vulnerabilities or insecure storage.
threats.mitigation: Implement proper data encryption at rest and in transit, and follow secure coding practices to prevent client-side data leaks.

labelText.text:
(1) Customer logs into
the merchant site

data.name:
(1) Customer logs into
the merchant site

threats.title: Authentication Flow Interception
threats.description: Flow (1) carries authentication data (OAuth) from Customer to Customer Client across the Customer/Internet boundary. The protocol is HTTPS but flows through public networks, making it vulnerable to interception if TLS is not properly implemented.
threats.mitigation: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with strong cipher suites and implement certificate pinning for authentication endpoints.

labelText.text:
(2) Customer proceeds to payment page
to make a purchase

data.name:
(2) Customer proceeds to payment page
to make a purchase

threats.title: Payment Flow Tampering
threats.description: Flow (2) carries payment initiation data from Customer to Customer Client using HTTPS over public networks. The flow could be intercepted and modified to alter payment details.
threats.mitigation: Implement end-to-end encryption and digital signatures to ensure payment data integrity throughout the transaction flow.

labelText.text:
(7) Customer provides card details
and finalizes payment

data.name:
(7) Customer provides card details
and finalizes payment

threats.title: Card Data Interception
threats.description: Flow (7) carries sensitive card details from Customer to Customer Client. The flow crosses trust boundaries and lacks explicit encryption specification, creating risk of card data exposure.
threats.mitigation: Implement PCI DSS compliant card data handling, including end-to-end encryption and tokenization to prevent card data exposure.

labelText.text:
(3) Customer Client sends order intent
including order amount
(6) Return PaymentIntent to
the Customer Client

data.name:
(3) Customer Client sends order intent
including order amount
(6) Return PaymentIntent to
the Customer Client

threats.title: Order Intent Manipulation
threats.description: Bidirectional flow (3/6) carries order intent and PaymentIntent between Customer Client and Merchant Web Server across trust boundaries. The flow lacks explicit encryption and could be modified in transit.
threats.mitigation: Implement message-level encryption and digital signatures for all order and payment intent communications between systems.

threats.title: Payment Intent Repudiation
threats.description: Bidirectional flow (3/6) handles payment transactions without explicit non-repudiation mechanisms. Parties could deny involvement in payment transactions.
threats.mitigation: Implement comprehensive audit logging and digital signatures for all payment-related transactions to prevent repudiation.

threats.title: Payment Service Denial of Service
threats.description: Flow (9) from Stripe API service to Stripe Payment Service represents internal payment processing. This critical flow could be targeted for DoS attacks, disrupting payment processing.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate limiting, circuit breakers, and redundant payment processing services to maintain availability during attack scenarios.

threats.title: Payment Response Tampering
threats.description: Flow (10) carries payment response data between Stripe Payment Service and Stripe API service. Tampering with payment responses could lead to incorrect transaction status reporting.
threats.mitigation: Implement secure internal communications with message authentication codes and integrity verification for all payment status messages.

threats.title: Payment Status Information Disclosure
threats.description: Flow (11) returns PaymentIntent status from Stripe API service to Customer Client across multiple trust boundaries. Sensitive payment status information could be exposed during transmission.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all payment status communications and implement proper access controls to ensure only authorized parties receive transaction status information.

threats.title: Card Payment API Abuse
threats.description: Flow (8) carries e.ConfirmCardPayment() from Customer Client to Stripe API service across trust boundaries. Unauthorized access to this API could allow privilege escalation for payment processing.
threats.mitigation: Implement strict API authentication, authorization checks, and rate limiting for all payment confirmation requests to prevent unauthorized payment processing.

threats.title: PaymentIntent Tampering
threats.description: Flow (5) returns PaymentIntent from Stripe API service to Merchant Web Server. Tampering with PaymentIntent data could lead to incorrect payment processing or financial losses.
threats.mitigation: Implement secure API communications with message integrity verification and digital signatures for all PaymentIntent data exchanges.

labelText.text:
(4) Merchant sends order information
inc amount and currency

data.name:
(4) Merchant sends order information
inc amount and currency

threats.title: Order Information Interception
threats.description: Flow (4) carries order information including amount and currency from Merchant Web Server to Stripe API service across trust boundaries. Sensitive order data could be exposed during transmission.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all order information in transit and implement secure API authentication to protect sensitive business data.

threats.title: Merchant Server Privilege Escalation
threats.description: Merchant Web Server process handles payment transactions and communicates with both customer-facing systems and Stripe API. Compromise could lead to unauthorized payment processing or data access.
threats.mitigation: Implement principle of least privilege, regular security updates, and strict access controls for merchant server components.

threats.title: Merchant Server Denial of Service
threats.description: Merchant Web Server is critical for payment processing and located in the Merchant/Web boundary. DoS attacks could disrupt the entire payment flow for customers.
threats.mitigation: Implement DDoS protection, load balancing, and auto-scaling capabilities to maintain service availability during high traffic or attack scenarios.

threats.title: API Service Authorization Bypass
threats.description: Stripe API service process handles payment requests and is located in the Stripe/Web boundary. Weak authentication could allow unauthorized access to payment processing functions.
threats.mitigation: Implement strong API authentication with OAuth 2.0, API keys, and comprehensive authorization checks for all payment operations.

threats.title: API Service Tampering
threats.description: Stripe API service processes sensitive payment data and coordinates between multiple systems. Compromise could allow tampering with payment transactions or data.
threats.mitigation: Implement secure coding practices, regular security testing, and integrity monitoring for API service components.

threats.title: Payment Service Privilege Escalation
threats.description: Stripe Payment Service process handles core payment processing within the Stripe/Web boundary. Unauthorized access could lead to financial fraud or data compromise.
threats.mitigation: Implement strict access controls, segregation of duties, and regular security audits for payment service components.

threats.title: Payment Service Information Disclosure
threats.description: Stripe Payment Service processes highly sensitive payment card data. Compromise could lead to massive data breach of customer payment information.
threats.mitigation: Implement PCI DSS compliance measures including encryption, tokenization, and strict access controls for payment card data processing and storage.
